Miembai -100 019. bidiu Received 5 February 1997: received in revised form 10 April 1997; accepted 18 April 1997 Iron oxide (Fe'03) offers Lewis acidic sites for alkylation but gives low yield and cannot be reused. Therefore, spinels belonging to system CuCr=,-Fe,04 were prepared by isomorphic substitution of octahedral chromium by iron in the spinet lattice. These were found to have better catalytic activity for the liquid phase alkylation of benzene with benzyl chloride giving diphenylmethane. CuFe204 gives the highest yield. The Lewis acidity of the catalysts is mainly responsible for the good catalyst performance. The ease of electron movement appears to improve the yields. The properties of these catalysts were characterized by using DRIFT spectroscopy. The effects of various parameters on the catalytic reaction have been investigated. ~(- 1998 Elsevier Science B.V. Introduction Mixed metal oxides possessing spinel structure have been investigated by a number of workers [1-4] as they exhibit interesting structural, electrical and magnetic properties. These properties are dependent on the nature of ions, their charges and their distribution among tetrahedral and octahedral sites. Ternary oxides crystallizing with spinel structures were found to exhibit interesting solid state and catalytic properties. Spinel oxides are a class of ternary oxides with composition AB104, wherein the A-ions occupy a tetrahedral site and B-ions occupy octahedral sites. *Corresponding author. Copper-based catalysts have attained considerable importance, owing to their selective properties in reactions involving hydrogen [8]. Metal chromites have been extensively used as hydrogenation catalysts [9,10]. Individual metal oxides loose their catalytic activity rapidly owing to aging and formation of coke over the catalyst surface. The spinel lattice imparts extra stability to the catalysts under various reaction conditions so that these systems have sustained activities for longer periods [5]. Ferrites have been used as catalysts for some industrially important reactions such as oxidative dehydrogenation of butene to butadiene [11], hydrodesulfurization of petroleum crude [ l2], and treatment of automobile exhaust gas [ 13]. 136 S.P Ghorpade et al. lApplied Catalysis A: General 166 (1998) 135-142 Table 1 Chemical analysis of compounds synthesized by the co-precipitation technique showing stoichiometry Compound Cu% Cr% Fe% Obs. Therefore these catalysts can be used repeatedly. Hence in the present investigation, structural stability, catalytic activity and reusability of some metal oxides and spinels have been investigated. Fe203 provides acidic sites on the surface which can be of help in catalyzing the Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction. Along with Fe203, Cr203 and CuO were also checked for the catalytic activity. Metal oxides gave low catalytic activity and they were not reusable. In an attempt to increase the stability of the structure and to increase the Lewis acidity of the structure Fe-containing spinels were prepared. Copper-based spinel systems from CuCr204 to CuFe204, which have extra structural stability of spinels and catalytic activity of ferrites, have been studied. 2. Experimental 2.1. Catalyst preparation The various compositions of the spinel system CuCrz_XFeX04 were prepared by a co-precipitation technique [14-16]. Initially calculated amounts of each sulfate were dissolved in doubly distilled water and the precipitation of the hydroxide was carried out at a controlled pH of 9.0-9.5 using 10% NaOH solution. The precipitate was heated on a water bath (363 K) for 3-4 h and was oxidized by adding the required (calculated) amount of 30% H202 with con- stant stirring at 363 K. The precipitate was filtered and washed with doubly distilled water to remove excess of alkali and S04- ions. The compounds were dried in an oven at 383 K for 6 h and then calcined at 1173 K for 4 h. Spinels prepared by this method have high surface areas [16]. The formation of single spinel phase was ascertained by XRD. The stoichiometries of the composition were checked by chemical analysis and found to be in agreement with theoretical values. The results of chemical analyses are given in Table 1. Commercially available metal oxides were used directly with activation for catalytic activity and structural studies. 2.2. Structural analysis X-ray powder diffraction patterns were recorded on a diffractrometer (Siemens D-500 Krystalloflex) with a microprocessor controller, using nickel filtered Cu-ka radiation. The X-ray patterns of all the compositions indicated formation of a single spinel phase. 2.3. Transport studies Electrical resistivity measurements were made to determine the energy gap between valence and conduction band. Pellets were prepared from the sample (2 g) by applying a pressure of 10 000 psi.; the thickness of the pellets varied between 0.53 and 0.59 cm. Initially, pellets were heated slowly in air at the rate of 1 K min-1 to remove the binder and then fired at 1173 K, the sintering temperature, for 6 h. DC electrical resistivity measurements were carried out from S. P. Ghorpade et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 166 (1998) 135-142 room temperature to 773 K using the two-probe technique. An electric field of 20 V cm-1 was applied across the pellet and the resistivity was calculated using the equation p = 7rd2/4T (where d is the diameter, t the thickness and R is the resistance). From the variation of resistivity with temperature, the activation energy (band gap) was calculated. 2.4. Infrared studies FTIR studies of the system CuCr2-xFex04 and some metal oxides were done by using a JASCO-300E spectrometer (resolution 2 cm-1). To study the surface sites, DRIFT studies were performed on pyridine adsorbed on spinels and metal oxide surfaces. All the samples were activated in an oven at 423 K for 3 h before the measurement. The pyridine used was distilled in vacuum over P205 before each experiment. The samples were used in powder form and all operations were carried out on a conventional vacuum system. Powdered spinel samples were exposed to pyridine vapors under pressure for 3 h at room temperature; the evacuation was done at 423 K for 3 h. 2.5. Studies on catalysis Each composition of the system and Fe203, Cr203 and CuO was studied for its catalytic behavior towards alkylation of benzene with benzyl chloride. The reactor consisted of a glass vessel of 3.0 cm inner diameter and 150 ml volume. The reactor was equipped with glass baffles and was stirred by a four-bladed glass turbine stirrer. The reactor was kept in a constant temperature oil bath. In a typical run, a mixture containing 0.02 M (2.34 ml) benzyl chloride and benzene (10 ml) was brought to 353 K under agitation (750-3000 rpm) and the desired quantity of catalyst (catalyst was activated at 393 K for 1 h just before use) was added. Each run was optimized for a desired time. Then the catalyst was washed with hot alcohol and any excess of alcohol was distilled out to obtain the products diphenylmethane and unreacted benzyl chloride. Unreacted benzyl chloride was removed by complexing with triethylamine and washing the products repeatedly with water to remove the benzyl chloride-triethylamine complex. The product is then dried over Na2S04. Purity of the sample was checked on TLC and GC. 137 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Characterization of the catalyst 3.1.1. X-ray studies The results of X-ray analysis indicate formation of single spinel phase. CuCr204 was found to be tetragonal. When the chromium in the spinel lattice was substituted by iron, the crystal lattice changes from tetragonal to cubic and CuFe204 was found to be cubic. 3.1.2. Transport studies The room temperature resistivity values of all compounds varied between 106 and 103 S2 cm for different values of x. The electrical resistivity temperature behavior was found to obey Wilson's law: p = po exp(DE/rT). Here p is the resistivity in SZ-1 cm-t, DE the activation energy, K the Boltzmann constant, T the absolute temperature and po is the constant. This indicates the semiconducting nature of all the compounds under investigation. The values of activation energy obtained from resistivity plots are plotted in Fig. 1. It can be seen that progressive substitution of iron for chromium in the system results in the decrease of activation energy from 0.38 eV for CuCr204 to 0.13 eV for CuCrFe04. Further substitution of iron increases the activation energy up to 0.19 eV for CuFe204. IR studies Oxidic spinels are known to crystallize in the cubic form with the space group Fd3m(oh7). The space group point symmetries and group theoretical calculations show four IR active fundamentals in the vibrational spectra of normal as well as inverse spinels. The two high frequency bands are broad and tend to be asymmetric, while low frequency bands are weak and sharp. On the basis of IR studies of oxidic spinels using methods of isomorphic and isotopic substitution, Preudhomme and Tarte [ 18-20] have reported that the high frequency bands v, and v2 are the vibrations of condensed octahedra. 1.3 is reported to be related to a complex vibration involving the participation of both types of cations, tetrahedral and octahedral. The low frequency v4 is assigned to some type of vibrations involving a displacement of tetrahedral cation. Cu 2+ ions are tetrahedral cations in the spinel system CuCr2-xFeX04. Since tetrahedral cations have not been displaced, the low frequency v4 type of vibrations is not studied in detail. The v3 vibrations which are due to the participation of both types of cations, tetrahedral and octahedral, have not been discussed in detail because of their complex nature. Cr3+ ions are the octahedral ions in case of the compound CuCr204. This Cr3+ octahedral ions are isomorphically replaced with Fe 3+ ions. Hence vl and v2 vibrations which may be attributed to the condensed octahedra are of relevance in the present case. In CuCr204, the Cr3+ will occupy half the octahedral interstices. The vl and v2 for CuCr204 were observed at 678 and 534 cm-' as broad bands. In CuFe204, vl and v2 are observed at 457 and 425 cm-' . In all the intermediate compositions, the values of v, and v2 change significantly. Let us consider the case of CuCrFe04 where both the octahedral ions are equally present. The bands at frequencies 700 and 582 cm-' are for octahedral chromium; those at 461 and 434 cm-' are due to octahedral iron. Thus one has to consider the vt and 1.2 for chromium octahedra and v, and v2 for the iron octahedra separately. It is obvious from Table 2 that values of v, and v2 for Cr06 octahedra increase with decrease in Cr content and those of Fe06 octahedra decrease with increase in Fe content. Thus, the trend in both the cases is similar. The v2 values of both the octahedra are due to the Cr-O and Fe-O stretching vibrations. In case of CUCr204, the stretching vibration in the range 425-473 cm-' due to Fe-O is absent. For CuFe204, the stretching vibration in the range 534-599 cm-' due to Cr-O is absent. But in the case of CuCrFe04, both Cr-O stretching at 582 cm-1 and Fe-O stretching at 434 cm-' are present (Fig. 2). This confirms the assignments of the respective metal-oxygen stretching vibrations. It is obvious from the above observation that the stretching frequency depends upon the cation distribution between the tetrahedral and octahedral sites. Modification in the vibrational frequency may arise due to simultaneous changes in parameters such as cationic mass, the cation-oxygen distance, binding force and the unit cell dimensions. It is not possible to distinguish between relative contributions of these different factors at this stage. 3.7.4. It is seen that as the values of x increase from 0 to 1 the percentage yield of DPM also increases. It is evident from the spectra of adsorbed pyridine of these spinels (Table 3) that 19b vibration, which is the indication of Lewis acidity of the catalyst, goes on shifting towards higher frequency as x increases from 0 to 1. On the other hand, the activation energy of the catalyst, which is the energy gap between valence band and conduction band goes on decreasing as x increases from 0 to 1 (Fig. 1). Both these factors together synergistically increase the formation of DPM. The small magnitude of the energy gap rules out the possibility of holes taking part in the reaction. Moreover, the lowering of the value with increase in iron content facilitates the free movement of the electrons in the conduction band. This in turn promotes the formation of carbocations. A Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction is an aromatic electrophilic substitution reaction in which the carbocation is formed by complexation of alkyl halide with the catalyst. The carbocation then attacks the aromatic species for alkylation. Formation of carbocation is thus an important step in the reaction mechanism. Lewis acidic centers on the catalysts surface due to Fe substitution facilitates the carbocation formation. Therefore the percentage yield of DPM increases as x increases from 0 to 1. However, for the values of x above 1, the values of activation energy increase, which results in a slight decrease in the formation of DPM. The activation energy continues to increase from 1.5 to 2.0; but, due to a preponderance of Fe Lewis sites which play major roles, the formation of DPM increases. Lower yields in the case of individual metal oxides may be due to the higher activation energy and lower strength of Lewis acidic sites. We believe that the high strength Lewis sites are provided by the octahedral Fe in the substituted spinels as well as in CuFe,04. As far as chromium ions are concerned these do not seem to generate strong enough catalytic activity in spine/ to catalyze Friedel-Crafts reaction which requires strong Lewis acidity. 3.3. Catalyst reusability Metal oxides: Fe203, Cr203 and Cu0 were not found to be reusable. However, all the compositions of the spine/ system were found to be reusable after washing with hot alcohol and activating at 523 K. Spine/ structure remains intact even after the reaction. This was confirmed by recording the IR spectra of the catalyst used. The catalysts were tested five times without any loss in the activity. 4. Conclusions Copper-based spinels have a good catalytic reactivity for Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction in liquid phase. Both Lewis and Brsted acidic sites are pre- 142 S.P Ghorpade et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 166 (1998) 135-142 sent. The number of the Lewis acidic sites increases as the iron content of the system increases. As the iron content increases, the activation energy of the catalyst decreases. Reactivity of the catalyst for the FriedelCrafts reaction is basically due to the surface Lewis acidity of the spinels. This is further promoted by the low values of the activation energy, which result in ease of electron movement. Dixit * Department of Chemical Technology, Applied Chemistry Division, University of Bombay, Matunga, Mumbai 400 019, India * Corresponding author. 1 Present address: Institute of Sciences, Madam Cama Road, Mumbai 400 022, India. Iron oxide (Fe2O3) offers Lewis acidic sites for alkylation but gives low yield and cannot be reused. Therefore, spinels belonging to system CuCr2−x Fe x O4 were prepared by isomorphic substitution of octahedral chromium by iron in the spinel lattice. These were found to have better catalytic activity for the liquid phase alkylation of benzene with benzyl chloride giving diphenylmethane. CuFe2O4 gives the highest yield. The Lewis acidity of the catalysts is mainly responsible for the good catalyst performance. The ease of electron movement appears to improve the yields. The properties of these catalysts were characterized by using DRIFT spectroscopy. The effects of various parameters on the catalytic reaction have been investigated.
